name: Overview
main:
The number of people affected by acute food insecurity climbed from 700,000 in February 2016 to 3.4 million in July 2017. Drought was declared a national disaster in February 2017. Most of the affected people are in arid and semi-arid lands, with conditions worst in Kilifi, Lamu, Marsabit, Tana River, and Turkana counties. The drought has deteriorated livestock conditions, water supplies, reduced harvests, and has caused conflict over resources.

A cholera outbreak is affecting Nairobi, Garissa, Turkana, Kilifi, Kajiado, Machakos, and Vihiga.

Kenya also hosts one of the largest refugee populations in the world, at just above 500,000, including over 300,000 from Somalia.

INFORM measures Kenya’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.9/10. ?
latest_developments_past:
22/12: Livestock deaths related to the drought were reported in November in various counties, including Isiolo, Marsabit, and Kajiado. ?

10/11: As of 10 November, some 280 people are displaced in Marsabit by localised floods caused by heavy rains that are affecting north and central Kenya. ?

25/09: Cholera case fatality rate (CFR) increases from 1.5% to 1.8% in September.
